questions.text: A 68-year-old woman has progressively worsening difficulty finding words during conversations. Her speech is fluent, she can follow commands and repeat phrases, but struggles to name common objects. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anomic aphasia

 

Option C:

 

Anomic aphasia is the inability to find the right words, particularly nouns and verbs, while other language functions are relatively preserved.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Broca's aphasia: Broca's aphasia is characterized by non-fluent, effortful speech.

 

Option B. Wernicke's aphasia: Presents with fluent but nonsensical speech and poor comprehension.

 

Option D. Global aphasia: Global aphasia is a severe impairment in all aspects of language.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize anomic aphasia as a specific type of aphasia primarily affecting word-finding ability.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of hypertension and TIAs is found unresponsive. On exam, he's awake but unable to follow commands or produce meaningful speech, only uttering repetitive sounds. He has right-sided hemiparesis and facial droop. CT shows a large left MCA infarct. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Global aphasia

 

Option D:

 

The severe impairment in both speech production and comprehension, combined with the right-sided hemiparesis and large left MCA infarct, indicates global aphasia.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Broca's aphasia: Broca's aphasia is non-fluent but comprehension is relatively preserved.

 

Option B. Wernicke's aphasia: Wernicke's aphasia is fluent but nonsensical, with poor comprehension.

 

Option C. Anomic aphasia: Anomic aphasia is primarily a word-finding difficulty with otherwise preserved language.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that global aphasia is the most severe form of aphasia, typically resulting from large lesions in the dominant hemisphere.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with hypertension has sudden difficulty reading. Words appear jumbled. He can write and understand spoken language but cannot read what he just wrote. He has right homonymous hemianopia. What is the most likely vascular territory affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left temporal lobe

 

Option D:

 

The combination of alexia without agraphia (inability to read with preserved writing) and right homonymous hemianopia (loss of the right visual field in both eyes) localizes to the left temporal lobe, specifically the splenium of the corpus callosum and the left occipital lobe.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Left ACA: ACA strokes affect the medial aspects of the frontal and parietal lobes, causing contralateral leg weakness and sensory loss.

 

Option B. Left MCA: MCA strokes affect the lateral aspects of the brain, causing contralateral face and arm weakness, sensory loss, and aphasia if in the dominant hemisphere.

 

Option C. Right PCA: PCA strokes affect the occipital lobe, causing visual field deficits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the classic presentation of alexia without agraphia, a syndrome caused by damage to specific regions of the left temporal lobe, often due to stroke.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man has difficulty writing, calculating, distinguishing left from right, and recognizing objects by touch. He has intact speech and follows commands. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gerstmann syndrome

 

Option B:

 

The classic tetrad of agraphia (writing difficulty), acalculia (calculation difficulty), finger agnosia (inability to recognize fingers) and left-right disorientation defines Gerstmann syndrome, typically caused by a lesion in the dominant (usually left) parietal lobe.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Wernicke's aphasia: Affects language comprehension and expression, not these specific skills.

 

Option C. Hemispatial neglect: Involves ignoring one side of space, not the deficits seen here.

 

Option D. Ideomotor apraxia: Ideomotor apraxia is the inability to perform learned motor tasks despite intact motor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize Gerstmann syndrome, a rare but classic neurological syndrome with specific deficits related to parietal lobe function.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypertension presents with sudden right-sided weakness, difficulty walking, confusion, and difficulty following instructions. On exam, he has right lower extremity weakness, urinary incontinence, apraxia, and intact speech. Which artery is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left ACA

 

Option B:

 

The symptoms of right leg weakness, incontinence (frontal lobe dysfunction), apraxia (motor planning difficulty), and mild cognitive impairment point to a left ACA stroke affecting the medial frontal and parietal lobes.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Right MCA: Right MCA stroke would cause left-sided weakness, sensory loss, and possible aphasia.

 

Option C. Right PCA: Right PCA stroke would mainly cause visual field deficits.

 

Option D. Left basilar artery: Left basilar artery stroke would result in more widespread brainstem symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the distinct clinical features of ACA stroke, particularly the lower extremity weakness, frontal lobe dysfunction, and urinary incontinence.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with hypertension has sudden difficulty reading, with words appearing jumbled. He can write and understand spoken language but cannot read what he just wrote. He also has right homonymous hemianopia. Which artery is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PCA

 

Option C:

 

The combination of alexia without agraphia (inability to read with preserved writing) and right homonymous hemianopia (loss of the right visual field in both eyes) is characteristic of a lesion in the left occipital lobe and splenium of the corpus callosum, which is typically supplied by the PCA.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. ACA: Supplies the medial frontal and parietal lobes, causing contralateral leg weakness and sensory loss.

 

Option B. MCA: Supplies the lateral frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes, causing contralateral face and arm weakness, sensory loss, and aphasia if in the dominant hemisphere.

 

Option D. ICA: Main artery supplying the anterior circulation of the brain, occlusion would cause more extensive deficits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the specific visual and reading deficits associated with PCA strokes.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents with progressive memory loss, difficulty recalling recent events and naming objects, fluent but with word-finding difficulty, and trouble with complex tasks. MRI shows generalized cortical atrophy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alzheimer's dementia

 

Option A:

 

Progressive memory loss, anomia, fluent aphasia, and executive dysfunction with generalized cortical atrophy on MRI strongly suggest Alzheimer's dementia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Frontotemporal dementia: Frontotemporal dementia presents with early personality and behavioral changes or primary progressive aphasia.

 

Option C. Vascular dementia: Vascular dementia has a stepwise decline with focal neurological signs.

 

Option D. Lewy body dementia: Lewy body dementia presents with fluctuating cognition, hallucinations, and Parkinsonism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the typical presentation and imaging findings of Alzheimer's dementia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a 4-month history of progressive proximal muscle weakness, with difficulty climbing stairs, rising from a chair, and lifting objects overhead. Exam reveals symmetrical proximal muscle weakness with preserved distal strength. Muscle tone and reflexes are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Myopathy

 

Symmetrical proximal muscle weakness without sensory or reflex abnormalities is the classic presentation of a myopathy, a disorder primarily affecting muscle tissue.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. UMN lesions: UMN lesions would cause spasticity and hyperreflexia.

 

Option B. LMN lesions: LMN lesions would cause weakness, atrophy, and fasciculations.

 

Option C. NMJ lesions: NMJ lesions Would cause fluctuating weakness and fatigability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the characteristic presentation of myopathy, a disorder primarily affecting muscle tissue.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man has significant personality changes, impulsivity, apathy, decreased hygiene, voracious appetite for sweets, and language deterioration over the past year. Memory and spatial orientation are intact. MRI shows frontal and anterior temporal lobe atrophy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Frontotemporal dementia

 

Option B:

 

The primary features of personality and behavioral changes, language decline, and relatively spared memory with frontotemporal atrophy on MRI are highly characteristic of frontotemporal dementia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alzheimer's dementia:  Alzheimer's primarily affects memory early on.

 

Option C. Vascular dementia: Vascular dementia has a stepwise decline with focal neurological signs.

 

Option D. Lewy body dementia: Lewy body dementia presents with fluctuating cognition, hallucinations, and parkinsonism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the distinctive early features of frontotemporal dementia, with prominent behavioral and language changes rather than memory loss.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with progressive personality changes, inappropriate behavior, lack of empathy, difficulty naming objects, and impaired executive function. Memory is relatively preserved. MRI shows marked atrophy in the frontal and temporal lobes, more pronounced on the right side. What pathology is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tau-positive inclusions

 

Option C:

 

Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is characterized by tau-positive inclusions, particularly in Pick's disease (a subtype of FTD), which lead to neurodegeneration in the frontal and temporal lobes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Beta-amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles:  Amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles are hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option B. Lewy bodies and alpha-synuclein pathology: Lewy bodies are associated with Lewy body dementia and Parkinson's disease.

 

Option D. Multiple lacunar infarcts: Lacunar infarcts are associated with vascular dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the neuropathology of frontotemporal dementia, primarily involving tau-positive inclusions leading to degeneration of the frontal and temporal lobes.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with complete loss of sensation and movement in both legs below the umbilicus after a motorcycle accident. He also reports loss of bladder and bowel control. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Complete spinal cord transection

 

Option D:

 

Complete loss of sensation and motor function below a specific level, along with loss of bowel and bladder control, is indicative of a complete spinal cord transection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cauda equina syndrome: Causes lower back pain, radicular pain, saddle anesthesia, and bowel/bladder dysfunction, but usually not complete paralysis.

 

Option B. Central cord syndrome: Typically presents with greater weakness in the upper extremities.

 

Option C. Anterior cord syndrome: Causes loss of motor function and pain/temperature sensation below the lesion, but proprioception is preserved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the signs of complete spinal cord transection, a devastating injury with complete loss of sensory and motor function below the level of injury.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with progressive cognitive decline, fluctuating attention, visual hallucinations, slow shuffling gait, stiffness, falls, and acting out dreams. Examination reveals mild rigidity and bradykinesia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lewy body dementia

 

Option C:

 

This clinical presentation of fluctuating attention, visual hallucinations, Parkinsonism, and REM sleep behavior disorder (acting out dreams) is highly suggestive of Lewy body dementia.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Alzheimer's disease: Alzheimer's disease has progressive memory loss as the main feature.

 

Option B. Vascular dementia: Vascular dementia has a stepwise decline related to vascular events.

 

Option D. Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH):  Presents with gait disturbance, incontinence, and cognitive decline, without the hallucinations or sleep disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the key features of Lewy body dementia that differentiate it from other forms of dementia.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman was stabbed in the back and now has decreased sensation on the right side of her body and weakness in her left leg. She has decreased pain and temperature sensation on the right below the mid-thorax, and decreased strength and vibratory/proprioceptive sensation on the left below the mid-thorax. What is the most likely spinal level of the injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T5-T6

 

Option B:

 

This presentation is characteristic of Brown-Séquard syndrome, a hemisection of the spinal cord. The sensory level corresponds to the mid-thorax, indicating injury around T5-T6.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. C5-C6: C5-C6 would involve the arms and upper chest.

 

Option C. L1-L2: L1-L2 would affect the legs and lower abdomen.

 

Option D. S1-S2: S1-S2 would affect the perineal area and bowel/bladder function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the patterns of sensory and motor loss in Brown-Séquard syndrome and how to localize the spinal level of injury.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man has progressive difficulty walking, cognitive decline, and urinary incontinence. His gait is slow and shuffling. MRI shows enlarged ventricles with normal cerebral sulci. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH)

 

Option C:

 

The triad of gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and cognitive decline with enlarged ventricles on MRI is characteristic of NPH.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alzheimer's disease: Alzheimer's mainly affects memory.

 

Option B. Vascular dementia: Vascular dementia is associated with vascular events.

 

Option D. Parkinson's disease:  Parkinson's primarily affects motor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the classic presentation of NPH, a potentially reversible cause of dementia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with progressive difficulty walking, cognitive decline, and urinary incontinence has ventriculomegaly on MRI. A lumbar puncture with large-volume CSF removal temporarily improves her gait. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt surgery

 

Option B:

 

Given the clinical presentation of NPH, the characteristic MRI findings, and the positive response to CSF removal, VP shunt surgery is the definitive treatment to drain excess CSF and improve symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Start a cholinesterase inhibitor:  Cholinesterase inhibitors are used in Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option C. Increase physical therapy:  Physical therapy can be helpful, but the underlying problem is excess CSF.

 

Option D. Start dopamine agonist therapy:  Dopamine agonists are used in Parkinson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that VP shunt surgery is the definitive treatment for NPH after a positive response to CSF removal.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man with uncontrolled hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and a previous stroke presents with stepwise decline in memory, attention, and problem-solving over the past year. He also has a history of TIAs. Exam shows mild right-sided weakness and brisk reflexes. Brain imaging shows multiple infarcts and chronic small vessel disease. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vascular dementia

 

Option D:

 

The stepwise decline in cognition, history of stroke/TIAs, focal neurological deficits, and imaging evidence of multiple infarcts and small vessel disease are characteristic of vascular dementia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alzheimer's disease:  Alzheimer's has a gradual, progressive decline without the stepwise pattern or focal signs.

 

Option B. Lewy body dementia: Lewy body dementia presents with fluctuating cognition, hallucinations, and Parkinsonism.

 

Option C. Frontotemporal dementia:  Frontotemporal dementia primarily affects personality and behavior or language.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the clinical features and imaging findings suggestive of vascular dementia, which is often related to cerebrovascular disease.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man has rapidly progressive memory loss, behavioral changes, and difficulty with coordination. He has myoclonic jerks, ataxia, startle response, periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG, and high signal abnormalities in the caudate and putamen on MRI DWI. CSF shows 14-3-3 protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)

 

Option B:

 

The rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, ataxia, characteristic EEG and MRI findings, and the presence of 14-3-3 protein in CSF strongly suggest Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alzheimer's disease: Alzheimer's has a slower progression and different clinical/imaging features.

 

Option C. Multiple sclerosis: Multiple sclerosis typically has relapsing-remitting course and different MRI findings.

 

Option D. Lewy body dementia: Lewy body dementia presents with fluctuating cognition, hallucinations, and Parkinsonism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the unique features of CJD, a rapidly progressive and fatal neurodegenerative disease with characteristic diagnostic findings.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a 2-year history of progressive difficulty walking and a resting tremor in his right hand that improves with movement also reports stiffness and difficulty buttoning his shirt. On exam, he has rigidity in the upper extremities and a shuffling gait with reduced arm swing. MRI brain is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parkinson's disease

 

Option B:

 

The classic triad of resting tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia (slowness of movement, including shuffling gait and reduced arm swing) in the absence of other neurological findings strongly suggests Parkinson's disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Essential tremor: Essential tremor is an action tremor that worsens with movement.

 

Option C. Huntington's disease: Involves chorea and cognitive decline.

 

Option D. Multiple system atrophy: Presents with Parkinsonism plus autonomic dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the classic clinical features of Parkinson's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder primarily affecting movement.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of left-hand resting tremors, stiffness in the left arm and leg, and bradykinesia. His father was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease at age 50. Genetic testing reveals a mutation associated with familial Parkinson's disease. Which gene is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) SNCA

 

Option C:

 

The SNCA gene encodes alpha-synuclein, the main component of Lewy bodies, and the pathological hallmark of Parkinson's disease (PD). Mutations in SNCA are strongly associated with familial forms of PD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. DJ-1: It is also associated with early-onset PD, but SNCA is more common.

 

Option B. HTT: It is the gene associated with Huntington's disease.

 

Option D. FUS: It is associated with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the association of SNCA gene mutations with familial Parkinson's disease.

choices.text: Onset of a secondary movement disorder

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with a 3-year history of Parkinson's disease on levodopa/carbidopa therapy develops sudden involuntary movements, nausea, and light headedness. On examination, she has choreiform movements, facial grimacing, and orthostatic hypotension. What is the most likely explanation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Levodopa-induced dyskinesia

 

Option B:

 

Levodopa-induced dyskinesia (LID) is a common side effect of long-term levodopa therapy in Parkinson's disease, characterized by involuntary movements like chorea and sometimes accompanied by orthostatic hypotension.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Parkinson's disease dementia: Is a cognitive decline, not a movement disorder.

 

Option C. Progression of Parkinson's disease: Disease progression usually causes worsening of the original motor symptoms, not new types of dyskinesia.

 

Option D. Onset of a secondary movement disorder: A secondary movement disorder is less likely given the clear temporal relationship with levodopa use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Recognize levodopa-induced dyskinesia as a common complication of long-term levodopa therapy in Parkinson's disease.

choices.text: Increase the frequency of levodopa/carbidopa dosing
Switch to a controlled-release formulation of levodopa/carbidopa

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a 4-year history of Parkinson's disease experiences "wearing-off" episodes and early morning tremors despite taking levodopa/carbidopa three times a day. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase the frequency of levodopa/carbidopa dosing

 

Option A:

 

Increasing the frequency of levodopa/carbidopa dosing is often the first-line approach to managing "wearing-off" phenomena in Parkinson's disease. This can help maintain more stable drug levels and reduce fluctuations in motor symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Adding a dopamine agonist: Can be considered, but it may worsen dyskinesia.

 

Option C. Add an MAO-B inhibitors: Add an MAO-B inhibitors are typically used in early Parkinson's disease or as an adjunct to levodopa.

 

Option D. Switch to a controlled-release formulation of levodopa/carbidopa: Controlled-release formulations may have unpredictable absorption and may not be effective in managing early morning off periods.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that adjusting the frequency of levodopa/carbidopa dosing is the preferred initial step in managing "wearing-off" phenomena in Parkinson's disease.

choices.text: Bilateral hyper intensities in basal ganglia

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents with progressive difficulty walking, frequent falls, cognitive decline and difficulty looking downward. She has a stiff posture and tends to fall backward. What MRI finding is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) "Hummingbird" sign with midbrain atrophy

 

Option C:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP). The "hummingbird" sign, characterized by midbrain atrophy on MRI, is a hallmark of PSP.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cerebellar and brainstem atrophy: Is more characteristic of multiple system atrophy (MSA).

 

Option B. Bilateral hyperintensities in basal ganglia: Are seen in other conditions like Wilson's disease.

 

Option D. Multiple white matter lesions:  Are seen in multiple sclerosis and other demyelinating disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the "hummingbird" sign on MRI as a key finding in PSP, which presents with gait difficulty, falls, cognitive decline, and vertical gaze palsy.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents with a 1-year history of balance difficulty, falls, right hand stiffness and clumsiness, forgetfulness, confusion, and visual hallucinations. Exam reveals increased tone, cogwheel rigidity, wide-based shuffling gait, impaired fine motor skills, and mild cognitive impairment. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Corticobasal syndrome (CBS)

 

Option C:

 

The asymmetric motor presentation (right-sided stiffness and clumsiness), cognitive impairment, and hallucinations are most consistent with CBS. The "alien hand" phenomenon is also often seen in CBS.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Multiple system atrophy (MSA):  MSA typically presents with autonomic dysfunction and Parkinsonism.

 

Option B. Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP):  PSP is characterized by early gait instability, falls, and vertical gaze palsy.

 

Option D. Lewy body dementia (LBD): LBD has more prominent fluctuations in cognition and visual hallucinations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the unique combination of motor, cognitive, and behavioral symptoms in CBS, distinguishing it from other parkinsonian syndromes.

choices.text: Trinucleotide repeat expansion in the HTT gene
Point mutation in the HTT gene
Hexanucleotide repeat expansion in the C9orf72 gene

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of involuntary jerking movements, mood swings, irritability, and cognitive decline. His father had similar symptoms in his 40s. Exam shows impaired rapid alternating movements and a positive Romberg sign. What genetic abnormality is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trinucleotide repeat expansion in the HTT gene

 

Option A:

 

The combination of chorea, cognitive decline, psychiatric symptoms, and a positive family history with autosomal dominant inheritance is highly suggestive of Huntington's disease, caused by CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the HTT gene.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Point mutations in the HTT gene: Are not typically associated with Huntington's disease.

 

Option C. Hexanucleotide repeat expansion in the C9orf72 gene: Is associated with ALS and frontotemporal dementia.

 

Option D. Deletions in the HTT gene: Are not the cause of Huntington's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the genetic basis of Huntington's disease and its characteristic clinical presentation.

choices.text: Location in the anterior communicating artery

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with hypertension and smoking presents with sudden severe "thunderclap" headache, nausea, and photophobia. CT reveals subarachnoid hemorrhage, and angiography shows a 7 mm berry aneurysm in the anterior communicating artery. Which factor most significantly increases the risk of rupture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Size of 7 mm

 

Option B:

 

Aneurysm size is the most critical predictor of rupture risk. Aneurysms > 7mm have a significantly higher chance of rupturing.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Location in the anterior communicating artery: Location can influence risk, but size is more significant.

 

Option C. History of hypertension: Hypertension is a risk factor for aneurysm formation and growth, but not the strongest predictor of rupture.

 

Option D. History of smoking: Smoking is a risk factor, but again, not as directly predictive as size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that aneurysm size is the most critical factor in determining rupture risk.

choices.text: World Federation of Neurological Surgeons (WFNS) grading system

questions.text: A 45-year-old man experiences a sudden, severe "thunderclap" headache while playing basketball. He has a stiff neck, photophobia, and CT reveals subarachnoid hemorrhage. Angiography shows a 4 mm aneurysm in the middle cerebral artery. Which grading scale is most appropriate to assess his SAH?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hunt and Hess scale

 

Option B:

 

The Hunt and Hess scale specifically grades the severity of SAH based on clinical presentation (headache, neurological deficits, level of consciousness), aiding in prognosis and management decisions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS):  GCS assesses level of consciousness but not the specific severity of SAH.

 

Option C. Modified Rankin Scale:  Modified Rankin Scale measures disability after stroke, not acute SAH severity.

 

Option D. World Federation of Neurological Surgeons (WFNS) grading system: WFNS grading system is another SAH scale, but Hunt and Hess is more commonly used for initial assessment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the role of the Hunt and Hess scale in assessing the severity and prognosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

choices.text: Cerebral salt wasting (CSW) due to SAH

questions.text: On day 5 post-SAH, a patient becomes confused and lethargic with a serum sodium of 125 mEq/L (down from 138 mEq/L). Fluid intake has been restricted, and there are no signs of edema or dehydration. What is the most likely cause of hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cerebral salt wasting (CSW) due to SAH

 

Option C:

 

CSW is a common cause of hyponatremia in SAH, characterized by renal sodium loss and volume depletion. This patient's history of fluid restriction and lack of overload make SIADH less likely.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Excessive hypotonic fluids:  Excessive fluids would cause fluid overload, not seen here.

 

Option B. SIADH secondary to SAH:  SIADH would present with euvolemia or fluid overload.

 

Option D. Adrenal insufficiency:  Adrenal insufficiency is less common and usually involves hypotension and hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize CSW as a potential cause of hyponatremia in SAH, differentiated from SIADH by volume status.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with poorly controlled hypertension presents with a sudden, severe "thunderclap" headache, nausea, and vomiting. She is drowsy with a stiff neck and positive Kernig's sign. CT reveals SAH and angiography shows a 5 mm aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nimodipine to prevent vasospasm

 

Option C:

 

While definitive treatment of the aneurysm is necessary, the immediate priority is preventing vasospasm, a major complication of SAH. Nimodipine, a calcium channel blocker, is the standard treatment for this.

 

Explanation:

 

Options A & B. Clipping or coiling are definitive treatments but not the immediate priority.

 

Option D. Corticosteroids are not indicated for SAH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the importance of nimodipine for preventing vasospasm in the acute management of SAH.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with repetitive, involuntary blinking, head jerking, and grunting noises for the past year. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tourette's syndrome

 

Option C:

 

The presence of both motor and vocal tics for more than one year is characteristic of Tourette's syndrome, a neurodevelopmental disorder.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD):  ADHD is characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity.

 

Option B. Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD):  OCD involves obsessions and compulsions.

 

Option D. Epilepsy: Epilepsy involves recurrent seizures, which are distinct from tics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the diagnostic criteria for Tourette's syndrome, a disorder characterized by motor and vocal tics.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with hypertension and smoking presents with sudden severe headache, confusion, and visual disturbances. He has bilateral papilledema and flame-shaped hemorrhages on fundoscopy. Brain MRI shows diffuse cerebral edema but no infarction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypertensive encephalopathy

 

Option B:

 

The sudden onset of headache, confusion, visual disturbances, and extremely high blood pressure, along with papilledema and cerebral edema on MRI, strongly suggest hypertensive encephalopathy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute ischemic stroke:  Ischemic stroke would show focal deficits and infarction on MRI.

 

Option C. Meningitis:  Meningitis would typically present with fever and neck stiffness.

 

Option D. Intracerebral haemorrhage: Intracerebral hemorrhage would show a focal bleed on MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the clinical and imaging features of hypertensive encephalopathy, a medical emergency requiring prompt blood pressure control.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypercholesterolemia presents with sudden-onset left-sided weakness, numbness, and difficulty speaking and understanding. He has left facial droop, hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, and global aphasia. A CT angiogram shows occlusion of the right ICA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right ICA stroke

 

Option C:

 

The combination of left-sided motor and sensory deficits along with global aphasia suggests a large right hemispheric stroke. The occlusion of the right ICA, which supplies both the MCA and ACA territories, explains the extensive deficits.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Right MCA stroke: Would not explain the full extent of deficits seen here.

 

Option B. Right ACA stroke: Typically affects the leg more than the face and arm.

 

Option D. Right PCA stroke: Would primarily cause visual field deficits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that ICA strokes can cause extensive deficits due to involvement of both the MCA and ACA territories.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypercholesterolemia has sudden-onset dizziness, nausea, vomiting, right-sided facial numbness, left-sided body numbness, ataxia, hoarse voice, and diminished gag reflex on the right. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome)

 

Option B:

 

The combination of crossed sensory findings (ipsilateral face, contralateral body), ataxia, and cranial nerve deficits (hoarseness, gag reflex) is classic for lateral medullary syndrome, usually caused by occlusion of the PICA or vertebral artery.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Medial medullary syndrome: Involves contralateral hemiparesis, contralateral proprioceptive loss, and ipsilateral tongue deviation.

 

Option C. Basilar artery stroke: Can cause a variety of symptoms, but the specific constellation here is more consistent with lateral medullary syndrome.

 

 Option D. Pontine stroke: Typically presents with bilateral motor deficits, facial weakness, and other cranial nerve palsies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the hallmark features of lateral medullary syndrome, a brainstem stroke with specific crossed sensory and cranial nerve findings.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with hypertension and atrial fibrillation is found unresponsive. On exam, she's awake but unable to speak or move any limbs, though she can blink and move her eyes vertically. She has quadriplegia and anarthria but is conscious. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Locked-in syndrome

 

Option B:

 

The acute onset of quadriplegia, anarthria (inability to speak), and preserved consciousness with only vertical eye movements strongly suggests locked-in syndrome, typically caused by a lesion in the ventral pons.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Guillain-Barré syndrome: Guillain-Barré syndrome is a progressive ascending paralysis, not sudden quadriplegia.

 

Option C. Myasthenia gravis: Causes fluctuating muscle weakness, not sudden and complete paralysis.

 

Option D. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS): ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disease with a slower onset.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the characteristic features of locked-in syndrome, a devastating condition where patients are fully conscious but unable to move or communicate verbally, except for vertical eye movements and blinking.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypercholesterolemia has sudden double vision, drooping right eyelid, enlarged pupil, and limited eye movement on the right. He also has tremors and ataxia in his left arm and leg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Benedikt's syndrome

 

Option B:

 

The combination of ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy (ptosis, mydriasis, ophthalmoplegia) and contralateral tremor and ataxia points towards Benedikt's syndrome, a midbrain lesion affecting the red nucleus and oculomotor nerve.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Weber's syndrome: Involves ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.

 

Option C. Claude's syndrome: Involves ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral ataxia, but not the prominent tremor seen here.

 

Option D. Millard-Gubler syndrome: Involves ipsilateral facial palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the unique features of Benedikt's syndrome, a midbrain lesion with a combination of oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral movement disorder.

questions.text: Familial hemiplegic migraine type 1 is caused due to mutation in?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. CACNA1A

Migraine genes identified by studying families with familial hemiplegic migraine (FHM) reveal involvement of ion channels, suggesting that alterations in membrane excitability can predispose to migraine. Mutations involving the Cav 2.1 (P/Q)–type voltage-gated calcium channel CACNA1A gene are now known to cause FHM 1.

Mutations in the Na+-K+ATPase ATP1A2 gene, designated FHM 2, are responsible for about 20% of FHMs. Mutations in the neuronal voltage-gated sodium channel SCN1A cause FHM 3.

 

 

Ref: Harrison’s 21st edition page no 3357

questions.text: MIDAS Questionnaire is used in evaluation of?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Migrane headache

 

 

Ref: Harrison’s 21st edition page no 3357

questions.text: Alcohol is trigger in which of the following type of headache?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cluster headache

 

 

Ref: Harrison’s 21st edition page no 3366

questions.text: Complete response to indomethacin is seen in which of the following type of headache?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Paroxysmal hemicrania

 

 

Ref: Harrison’s 21st edition page no 3366

questions.text: Most common blood vessel involved in trigeminal neuralgia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Superior cerebellar artery

Compression of the trigeminal nerve root by a blood vessel, most often the superior cerebellar artery or on occasion a tortuous vein, is believed to be the source of trigeminal neuralgia in most patients.

 

 

Ref: Harrison’s 21st edition page no 3437

choices.text: Elevate the head of the bed to 30 degrees

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia presents with sudden expressive aphasia, right facial droop, and right hemiparesis. He receives IV tPA, but 24 hours later his condition worsens, and repeat CT shows significant cerebral edema with midline shift. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intravenous mannitol

 

Option A:

 

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used to reduce cerebral edema and lower intracranial pressure, which is the primary concern in this patient with worsening neurological status and midline shift.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Elevate the head of the bed to 30 degrees:  Head elevation can help, but it's unlikely to be enough in this severe case.

 

Option C. Immediate decompressive craniectomy: Decompressive craniectomy is a last resort if medical management fails.

 

Option D. High-dose corticosteroids:  Corticosteroids are not recommended for cerebral edema in ischemic stroke.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the role of mannitol in managing increased intracranial pressure due to cerebral edema in stroke.

choices.text: Continue medical management with aspirin and statin therapy.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a 30-pack-year smoking history presents with right-sided weakness and aphasia. CT shows a left MCA stroke. Carotid duplex shows 80% stenosis of the left ICA. He is started on aspirin and a high-intensity statin. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schedule a carotid endarterectomy (CEA)

 

Option B:

 

Given the patient's recent ischemic stroke and significant (80%) stenosis of the ipsilateral ICA, CEA is recommended to reduce the risk of future strokes. CEA is often preferred over CAS in patients who are suitable surgical candidates.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Continue medical management with aspirin and statin therapy: Medical management alone is not sufficient for high-grade stenosis with recent symptoms.

 

Option C. Initiate anticoagulation with warfarin:  Anticoagulation is primarily for cardioembolic strokes, not carotid stenosis.

 

Option D. Perform carotid artery stenting (CAS):  CAS is an alternative for high-risk surgical patients, but CEA is generally preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In symptomatic patients with high-grade carotid stenosis, CEA is recommended to prevent future strokes.

choices.text: Continue warfarin with more frequent INR monitoring.
Switch to a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC).
Start dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation and hypertension on warfarin presents with left-sided weakness, slurred speech, and a right MCA stroke. Her INR is subtherapeutic (1.5). What is the most appropriate anticoagulation strategy going forward?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Switch to a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC)

 

Option B:

 

DOACs are preferred over warfarin for stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation due to their more predictable anticoagulant effect and lower bleeding risk. Switching to a DOAC is especially appropriate after a stroke while on subtherapeutic warfarin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Continue warfarin with more frequent INR monitoring:  Frequent INR monitoring may not guarantee optimal warfarin control.

 

Option C. Initiate aspirin therapy:  Aspirin is not sufficient for stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation.

 

Option D. Start dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel:  Dual antiplatelet therapy is not routinely recommended for atrial fibrillation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the advantages of DOACs over warfarin in stroke prevention for atrial fibrillation, especially in cases of subtherapeutic INR.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with hypertension and diabetes has a TIA with speech difficulty and right-sided weakness lasting 20 minutes. What is her ABCD2 score?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5

 

Explanation:

 

  • Age (0 points for <60 years old)
  • Blood pressure (1 point for ≥140/90 mmHg)
  • Clinical features (2 points for unilateral weakness)
  • Duration (1 point for 10-59 minutes)
  • Diabetes (1 point)

 

Total = 5

 

Educational Objective:

 

Know how to calculate the ABCD2 score, a clinical tool to assess stroke risk after a TIA.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with hypertension has acute dysarthria. MRI reveals a lacunar stroke. Which part of the brain is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Genu of internal capsule

 

Option C:

 

Dysarthria (slurred speech) in the context of a lacunar stroke often localizes to the genu of the internal capsule, which contains fibers of the corticobulbar tract responsible for speech articulation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Posterior limb: Affects contralateral limbs, causing hemiparesis.

 

Option B. Ventral thalamus: Affects sensory and motor relay, causing sensory disturbances or movement disorders.

 

Option D. Ventral pons: Could cause dysarthria but typically also involves hemiparesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the anatomy of lacunar strokes and how different locations can lead to specific neurological deficits.

choices.text: Aneurysmal dilation of the anterior communicating artery
Occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery (MCA)
Dissection of the right internal carotid artery
Arteriovenous malformation in the occipital lobe

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with hypertension presents with sudden severe headache, right-sided partial vision loss, and difficulty speaking. He has right homonymous hemianopia and slurred speech. CT head is normal. What is the MRA most likely to show?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery (MCA)

 

Option B:

 

The sudden onset of headache, aphasia, and homonymous hemianopia suggests an ischemic stroke in the left MCA territory. MRA would likely show the occlusion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aneurysmal dilation of the anterior communicating artery: Aneurysm would more likely present with subarachnoid hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Dissection of the right internal carotid artery: Carotid dissection could cause stroke, but the symptoms are more suggestive of MCA territory.

 

Option D. Arteriovenous malformation in the occipital lobe:  AVM would be visible on CT, and occipital AVM would likely cause only visual symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the presentation of MCA stroke and the role of MRA in confirming the diagnosis.

choices.text: Multiple hyperintense lesions in white matter on T2-weighted images
Acute infarction in the MCA territory

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with SLE and chronic kidney disease presents with sudden severe headache, blurred vision, confusion, and hypertension. Fundoscopy shows bilateral papilledema. MRI is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple hyperintense lesions in white matter on T2-weighted images

 

Option A:

 

This presentation is suggestive of posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES), often associated with hypertension and renal disease. MRI typically shows hyperintense white matter lesions on T2-weighted images.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Acute infarction in the MCA territory: MCA infarction would present with focal neurological deficits.

 

Option C. Meningeal enhancement: Meningeal enhancement suggests meningitis or meningeal carcinomatosis.

 

Option D. Normal brain parenchyma:  MRI in PRES is usually not normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the clinical and imaging features of PRES, a condition often associated with hypertension and renal dysfunction.

choices.text: Aneurysmal dilation of the anterior communicating artery

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with a sudden, severe "thunderclap" headache, different from her usual migraines. She recently started a new weight loss medication. CT head is normal, and LP shows no SAH. What is the MRA most likely to show?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beading of cerebral arteries

 

Option A:

 

This presentation suggests reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS), often triggered by medications. MRA typically shows the characteristic "beading" pattern of the cerebral arteries.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Aneurysmal dilation of the anterior communicating artery: Aneurysm would more likely present with SAH.

 

Option C. Occlusion of the left MCA: MCA occlusion would present with focal neurological deficits.

 

Option D. Normal cerebral vasculature:  Normal vasculature is unlikely in the presence of a vascular headache.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the presentation of RCVS and the characteristic "beading" pattern on MRA.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with sudden severe headache, vomiting, and confusion. He has a history of recurrent muscle weakness and pain after exercise, progressive hearing loss, and migraines. Exam shows lethargy, bilateral ptosis, and weakness. Fundoscopy reveals pigmentary retinopathy. Lactate is elevated in blood and CSF. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MELAS syndrome

 

Option C:

 

This presentation is classic for MELAS (Mitochondrial Encephalomyopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like episodes) syndrome, characterized by the triad of symptoms, muscle weakness, and elevated lactate levels.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Leigh syndrome:  Presents in infancy with developmental regression and respiratory abnormalities.

 

Option B. MERRF syndrome: Presents with myoclonus and ragged-red fibers on muscle biopsy.

 

Option D. Kearns-Sayre syndrome: Presents with ophthalmoplegia, pigmentary retinopathy, and heart block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the classic presentation of MELAS syndrome, a mitochondrial disorder with a multisystemic presentation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with uncontrolled hypertension presents unconscious with sudden severe headache, vomiting, pinpoint pupils, and a GCS of 6. CT shows a hemorrhage. What is the most likely site of the bleed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pons

 

Option B:

 

The sudden onset of severe headache, vomiting, pinpoint pupils, and rapid decline in consciousness strongly suggests a pontine hemorrhage, a common complication of uncontrolled hypertension.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Putamen:  Putaminal hemorrhages usually present with contralateral hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, and homonymous hemianopia.

 

Option C. Cerebellum: Cerebellar hemorrhages often present with ataxia and may not cause pinpoint pupils or rapid coma.

 

Option D.Thalamus: Thalamic hemorrhages usually present with sensory loss, hemiparesis, and upgaze palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the characteristic features of pontine hemorrhage, a life-threatening condition often associated with hypertension, requiring immediate medical attention.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation and hypertension on warfarin presents with right-sided weakness, slurred speech, and left MCA stroke. Her INR is 2.6. She is immobile due to hemiplegia. What is the most appropriate VTE prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH)

 

Option B:

 

LMWH is the preferred VTE prophylaxis in acute stroke patients due to its efficacy and lower bleeding risk compared to UFH. It can be safely used even if the patient is on warfarin, as long as the INR is not supratherapeutic.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Continue warfarin with INR 2-3:  Continuing warfarin may not provide adequate VTE prophylaxis in the acute setting.

 

Option C. Start unfractionated heparin (UFH) infusion:  UFH requires more frequent monitoring and adjustments.

 

Option D. No additional prophylaxis is needed:  Immobile stroke patients are at high risk for VTE and require prophylaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the importance of VTE prophylaxis in immobile stroke patients, and that LMWH is generally preferred over UFH.
